item.description:
Akira Kurosawa's YOJIMBO

Description: (1961) Directed by Akira Kurosawa. Screenplay by Akira Kurosawa, Ryuzo Kikushima, and Hideo Oguni. Cinematographer, Kazuo Miyagawa. Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Eijiro Tono, Kamatari Fujiwara, Takashi Shimura.

Kurosawa's classic film of a lone samurai (Toshiro Mifune) with an outdated sense of honor has inspired filmmakers from Sergio Leone to George Lucas to Quentin Tarantino. Slyly humorous and full of thrillingly choreographed action, the movie begins as Mifune is forced to take sides in a feud between two warring clans. Every frame of Yojimbo tells a story, from a dog running by with a human hand in its mouth, to the ironic resignation on the great swordsman's face when his enemy pulls a gun - the town's first - out of his flowing sleeve. "The best samurai film ever made... a treasure trove of attitude." - J. Hoberman.

110 minutes.

group.name: Beyond the Multiplex: Hartford's Indie and Foreign Film fans

item.name: YOJIMBO
